text: Federated learning trains models on distributed clients and aggregates updates without centralizing raw data.
Quantization reduces model memory and communication cost by representing weights and updates with fewer bits.
Secure aggregation masks client updates so a server can recover only an aggregate sum.
Non-IID data means each client sees a different data distribution, which can degrade federated optimization.
CPU-first model design focuses on low memory use and predictable latency on commodity devices.
Retrieval augmented generation combines a retriever with a generator to improve factual grounding.
A project board with transparent statuses improves coordination for open-source contributors.
Baseline regression checks in CI can prevent silent quality drops and enforce reproducibility.
Edge deployment requires careful tradeoffs among latency, battery use, and offline capability.
Model governance should document data provenance, licensing constraints, and release decisions.
Drop-out simulation in federated rounds measures resilience when some clients fail to report.
Communication compression can use sparse updates, quantization, and periodic synchronization.
Fairness in distributed systems includes balancing outcomes across high-capacity and low-capacity nodes.
Open model ecosystems benefit from clear contribution guides and public decision logs.
Latency benchmarks should report median and tail behavior to capture user-facing performance.
